_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Miscellaneous Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Hercules, Incorporated, Aqualon Division (Aqualon) owns and operates a guar manufacturing facility located One Mill Street, Kenedy, Karnes County, Texas.  The plant processes includes bulk storage of guar splits, alteration by chemical addition, and grinding.  Propylene oxide is stored in a bulk storage tank is delivered to the plant biweekly in tanker trucks.  The Risk Management Plan has been developed in accordance with ?Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions? under 40 CFR part 68.
The Aqualon facility uses Propylene Oxide above the threshold and is subject to Program 3 requirements.  Propylene Oxide is a listed regulated substance used in the P80 process and in the pilot plant.  RMP regulations define a Program 3 process to be one that has the potential for off-site impacts from a release and is subject to OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) program or is classified in one of nine Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) codes.

The Offsite Consequences Analysis
 The population estimates are very conservative (the numbers are likely much higher than actually existed in the year 2000 ? U.S. Census).  The Tiger/Line file was converted by the Office of the State Demographer into a ?shape? file.  The ?shape? file contains ?block? divisions for Karnes County, Texas for the U.S. Census Bureau 2000 data.  The block data file used in conjunction with the database file in ESRI ArcView 8.3 was used to determine the population density within each ?block? of interest.  The population density within each worst-case analysis area and the alternative case area was determined by intersecting the individual blocks within each circular area, using ArcView 8.3 Tools.  The population estimates are likely to be very conservative since the blocks do not share boundary with the circular areas of each scenario, but extend beyond in many instance and the population density within each block is assumed to be distributed uniformly throughout the block.  Consequently, where a block int

ersects the circle?s perimeter, the rest of block is dropped off beyond the perimeter, but the population estimate represents the density for the whole block.  As such, in many instances only a small portion of a block or partial block is contained within the circular area, so the estimates for these blocks are inflated.


    
The Accidental Release and Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Aqualon is dedicated to providing a safe and healthful environment for employees, customers, and communities.  Hercules? Aqualon facility is a OSHA VPP Star site.  This facility complies with all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  All management practices associated with Responsible Care Program compliance are reviewed annually to assure all provisions are in place and operational.  Detailed emergency plans are in place at the plant.  They perform emergency drills regularly.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled
Propylene oxide is handled in the bulk chemical storage and unloading area.  Typically, propylene oxide is delivered to the plant biweekly in tanker trucks with carry approximately 44,000 pounds each.  The truck is parked in the unloading area using procedures that assure the chemical holding portion of the truck is within the protected area.  The protected area has a trench around the perimeter, which is intended to catch any releases of propylene oxide.  The trench drains to a concrete lined neutralization pit where it can be pumped to another container or otherwise controlled.

The truck is hooked up to the unloading system using dry disconnect, 2-inch, stainless steel wire wrapped, flex hoses.  Dry disconnect hoses prevent release of chemical as the hoses are connected and disconnected.  Propylene oxide is pumped from the truck to the holding tank through stainless steel pipe.  All vapor associated with the unloading procedure is vented back to the truck with no release to the atmosphere.  The tank sits within a concrete containment dik

e which is inspected annually.
Unloading procedures for the propylene oxide are in place to assure all emergency equipment is functional prior to unloading and that the pumps and systems are leak free.  Carriers have dedicated propylene oxide trailers that have manual shut off valves, excess flow valves, and hydraulic lines that can be tripped on the way out of the area to stop the flow.  
All operators are certified in the unloading operation and are required to stay within 25 feet of the truck while unloading is taking place.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The propylene oxide system complies with EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and all applicable state codes and regulations.  The process equipment is designed and constructed in accordance with strict engineering standards.  Automatic shut off valves and propylene oxide sensors have been installed since the last RMP submittal.
The unloading hoses are not pressurized, other than to equalize pressure between the tank and the truck during the unloading process.  Hoses are checked for leaks prior to unloading by visual inspection and pressure testing.  Certified operators are trained to use emergency hydraulic shut off system associated with dedicated propylene oxide trucks which would stop the discharge.  

The Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidental release events over the past five years involving propylene oxide that have had on-site or off-site impacts.

The Emergency Response Program
Aqualon communicates regularly with the community responders.  In the event of an emergency involving the propylene oxide system, it is our policy to notify the Sheriff?s Office and Karnes County Local Emergency Response Agency to request for assistance.  LEPC and the City of Kennedy Fire Department are notified through the Sheriff?s Office. Detailed emergency plans are in place at the plant.  Emergency drills are performed regularly.

Planned Change

s to Improve Safety
This facility is in compliance with the local, state, and federal standards.  This facility continues to look for ways to improve and update Safety Program.
